distribution: This species is known only from the Río Marañón in the upper Amazon basin, Peru, and probably occurs in some tributaries draining into Peru from Ecuador.
torosus: from the Latin torosus, meaning ‘muscular, brawny’, in reference to this species’ body shape.

Aguarunichthys: in reference to the Aguaruna, an indigenous people of the Peruvian jungle who primarily live on the Marañón River in northern Peru near the border with Ecuador, plus the Ancient Greek ἰχθύς (ikhthus), meaning ‘fish’.
habitat: Aguarunichthys: in reference to the Aguaruna, an indigenous people of the Peruvian jungle who primarily live on the Marañón River in northern Peru near the border with Ecuador, plus the Ancient Greek ἰχθύς (ikhthus), meaning ‘fish’.
torosus: from the Latin torosus, meaning ‘muscular, brawny’, in reference to this species’ body shape.
This species is known only from the Río Marañón in the upper Amazon basin, Peru, and probably occurs in some tributaries draining into Peru from Ecuador.
Type locality is ‘Río Cenepa, Departo. Amazonas, Peru, about 4°28’S, 78°10’W, elevation about 210 meters’.
diet: An obligate predator feeding on other fishes in nature, but quality dried foods are normally accepted in captivity.
It should also be offered meaty fare such as strips of white fish, live earthworms, shrimp, etc., for optimal health.
Adult individuals are unlikely to require feeding on a daily basis with 2-3 meals per week sufficient.
behaviour: This species will eat fishes small enough to fit in its capacious mouth and is aggressively territorial towards conspecifics so is best-maintained as a single specimen in a community of larger, ideally fluvial, species.
Adult individuals are unlikely to require feeding on a daily basis with 2-3 meals per week sufficient.
It should also be offered meaty fare such as strips of white fish, live earthworms, shrimp, etc., for optimal health.
An obligate predator feeding on other fishes in nature, but quality dried foods are normally accepted in captivity.
The largest specimen known measured 346 mm.
Type locality is ‘Río Cenepa, Departo. Amazonas, Peru, about 4°28’S, 78°10’W, elevation about 210 meters’.
